nodes.bodyText: I haven't tested if this work, or if it just ends up being downloaded.
nodes.diffHunk:

  • +Specification +

  • +Namespace (turtle) +
    • +

nodes.bodyText:
I don't understand the setup. Why have an html file that links to another html file and a turtle file? Why not simply have a link to the turtle file inside the specification? For that matter, why have a turtle file at all?
Given that we have multiple files relating to the same thing, I'd prefer if we could organize this a little neater: a subdirectory, for one thing.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@ + + + + + Eclipse RDF4J SHACL Extensions + + +
    +
  • +Specification +
    • +
  • +Namespace (turtle) +
    • +
+

nodes.bodyText: Goal was that if you go to the namespace url, you end up at a page where you can choose if you want to read the spec or download the turtle file. The turtle file contains the schema for the namespace. We could also add the SHACL shapes for validating our extension to that turtle file. That's what SHACL does with their schema file.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,16 @@ + + + + + Eclipse RDF4J SHACL Extensions + + +
    +
  • +Specification +
    • +
  • +Namespace (turtle) +
    • +
+

nodes.bodyText: Fair enough. I've reorganized this slightly - the html file with the links has been moved to /content and changed to markdown (bonus is that it now uses our website theme). The spec and the schema file have been added to a subdir to keep things organized (also because in future we may want to publish more specs this way). Tested locally, the namespace resolves to the link page, so all works as intended.

nodes.bodyText: Do we need a CQ for this?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,263 @@
+<!DOCTYPE html>
+<html>
+<head>
+    <meta charset="utf-8">
+    <title>Eclipse RDF4J SHACL Extensions</title>
+    <script src="https://www.w3.org/Tools/respec/respec-w3c" class="remove" defer></script>

nodes.bodyText: Good point - I think we do. Actually worth verifying that it's acceptable before investing heavily. I doubt it's a problem, but W3C sometimes use a non-standard license for their software (although looking at the respec license at https://github.com/w3c/respec/blob/develop/LICENSE, it might be a BSD license). Best be sure that the legal team are ok with it.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,263 @@
+<!DOCTYPE html>
+<html>
+<head>
+    <meta charset="utf-8">
+    <title>Eclipse RDF4J SHACL Extensions</title>
+    <script src="https://www.w3.org/Tools/respec/respec-w3c" class="remove" defer></script>

nodes.bodyText: I have changed my mind on this actually. We are not distributing the respec code itself as part of our repo or as part of our project downloads, and from what I can tell of similar things in IPZilla (e.g. a CQ for a hugo theme that was withdrawn on advice of the IP team), they consider this kind of scenario low-risk enough that IP review is not necessary.

nodes.bodyText: Not sure if this is the place to do it, but I notice that the current rendered spec links to https://eclipse.github.io/rdf4j/ at the top (under "latest editor's draft"). Can we adjust that to link to the correct page?
